paper_metadata.title: The impact of social grants on rural household welfare in South Africa

component_a_cash_support.cash_support_type: social grants (disability grant, social pension, child support grant)
component_a_cash_support.cash_evidence_citation: Social grants variable in the Hlokozi survey was measured using a question 'indicate which member of your household receives the following grants or payments at present': disability grant, social pension and child support grant. The respondent is then asked to indicate the total sum per household per month.

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: We measure impacts on income, consumption, and asset ownership using an RCT design.
study_characteristics.study_design: Cross-sectional survey with propensity score matching
study_characteristics.design_evidence_citation: This study uses a cross-sectional household survey data conducted in Hlokozi village. A propensity score matching technique, which accounts for non-random selection of households, is applied.

evidence_citations.program_name_citation: Since the inception of democratic rule, South African government has turned to social grants to address the issues of poverty, income inequality and to improve household welfare.
evidence_citations.country_citation: This study aims to investigate the impact of social grants on rural household welfare in a village located in one of the poorest provinces in South Africa -KwaZulu Natal Province.
evidence_citations.target_population_citation: The coverage of social grants has increased substantially with more than 17 million (about 34% of the population) South Africans being recipients of social grants.
